C is wrong. assigning a user to a group doesn't achieve anything on it's own.
A is correct: As well as the DNS service, the firewall policy must specify the allowed protocols, such as HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, and Telnet. If the firewall policy that has authentication enabled does not allow at least one of the supported protocols used for obtaining user credentials, the user will not be able to authenticate.
FortiGate_Security_6.2_Study_Guide-Online (Page 233). The correct answer is C.
C is correct... under security profiles (web filter for example) at the firewall policy, you set the action to Authenticate and then select the group to actively authenticate
A is the correct one

choices.A: You must enable one or more protocols that support active authentication on a firewall policy.
choices.B: You must position the firewall policy for active authentication before a firewall policy for passive authentication
choices.C: You must assign users to a group for active authentication
choices.D: You must enable the Authentication setting on the firewall policy
Port address translation is not used.
choices.C: Connections are tracked using source port and source MAC address.
choices.B: Source IP is translated to the outgoing interface IP.
choices.A: This is known as many-to-one NAT.

questions.question_text: Which statements are true regarding firewall policy NAT using the outgoing interface IP address with fixed port disabled? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Answer is B&D because the fixed port is disabled, then no port address translation will take place

Selected Answer: AB
A. and B.
"When you select Use Outgoing Interface Address on the matching firewall policy, FortiGate uses the egress interface address as the NAT IP for performing SNAT. 

If there are multiple devices behind FortiGate, FortiGate performs many-to-one NAT. This is also known as PAT. FortiGate assigns to each connection sharing the egress interface address a port number from a pool of available ports. The assignment of a port enables FortiGate to identify packets associated with the connection and then perform the corresponding translation. This is the same behavior as the overload IP pool type, which you will also learn about. 

Optionally, you may select a fixed port, in which case the source port translation is disabled. With a fixed port, if two or more connections require the same source port for a single IP address, only one connection is established."

Reference: FortiGate 7.4 Administrator Study Guide, page 56

Selected Answer: BD
Answer is B&D
It is A&b
A y B son correctas, pag. 152 Fortigate_Security_6.2
A & B, Fixed port disable means that source port translation can be used,
also for me A & B

i think its 
B&D

comments.content: A&B are correct because the fixed port is disabled (default). If it is enable, then the answer would be C&D.

questions.question_text: Which statement is true regarding the policy ID number of a firewall policy?

discussion.content: https://help.fortinet.com/fos50hlp/52data/Content/FortiOS/fortigate-firewall-52/Security%20Policies/Policy%20identification.htm

When looking at the policy listing it can appear as if the policies are identified by the sequence number in the far left column. The problem is that this number changes as the position of the policy in the sequence changes. The column that correctly identifies the policy, and the value sticks with the policy is the "ID" column. This column is not shown by default in the listing but can be added to the displayed columns by right clicking on the column heading bar and selecting it from the list of possible columns.

When looking in the configuration file the sequence is based upon the order of the policies as they are in the file just as they are in the list in the GUI. However, if you need to edit the policy in the CLI you must use the ID number.

choices.A: Defines the order in which rules are processed.
choices.D: Changes when firewall policies are reordered.
choices.B: Represents the number of objects used in the firewall policy.
choices.C: Required to modify a firewall policy using the CLI.

discussion.content: A is correct. Fortigate Security guide 6.2 page 441.

comments.content: A is indeed the correct answer. Fortigate Security Study guide 6.0 page 411

discussion.content: guys who says that B is correct do you can explain why?

comments.content: Correct is A: limit the scope to browser-based
the keyword is "browser-based" which we can find only in the Answer A

discussion.content:
The answer is B. 
In the FortiGate_Security_6.2_Study_Guide-Online (page 443). It says:
"You can configure the URL category within the same firewall policy; however, adding a URL filter will cause application control to scan applications in only the browser-based technology category. For example, Facebook Messenger on the Facebook website."

The answer is B. 
In the FortiGate_Security_6.2_Study_Guide-Online (page 442). It says:
"You can configure the URL category within the same firewall policy; however, adding a URL filter will cause application control to scan applications in only the browser-based technology category. For example, Facebook Messenger on the Facebook website."
also for me is A

questions.question_text: What is the limitation of using a URL list and application control on the same firewall policy, in NGFW policy-based mode?

choices.C: It limits the scope of application control to scan application traffic using parent signatures only
choices.A: It limits the scope of application control to the browser-based technology category only.
choices.D: It limits the scope of application control to scan application traffic on DNS protocol only.
choices.B: It limits the scope of application control to scan application traffic based on application category only.

questions.question_text: The FSSO Collector Agent set to advanced access mode for the Windows Active Directory uses which of the following?

discussion.content: Answer is A: Advanced mode uses the LDAP convention, while Standard mode uses Windows convention NetBios
